name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: And designing intro reels is actually a fun part of the organizing process. That is actually a form of digital arts and crafts.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: There really is no shortcut in coaching speakers on how to speak on TEDx. You have to understand what your speakers want to say on stage before collaborating on how to make the content digestible to the audience while ensuring the content meet guidelines.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: How I combat topical disadvantages- I do homework on my speakers’ proposed topics outside of OT. I want to know what’s already out there before making a decision to accept, and ultimately on how to coach speakers.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: The hardest part of organizing TEDx for me is screening and then coaching speakers. Because of TED’s content diversity requirements, I don’t have as much of a home court advantage in terms topic curation as people think, even though my experiences as a speaker give me an edge.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: When other TEDx organizers email you for troubleshooting for post-event stuff during your time at your professional conference. I know I am glad to help other events out. 😄 #beinggoodneighbor

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: On my flight now to #aotainspire22. Sure didn’t know that I will get to reunite with some folks from @uscchanosot on the same flight. @ LAX Terminal https://t.co/nJCxjrvn2e

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Seeing some familiar faces from @USCChanOSOT on my flight to #AOTAINSPIRE22.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: If people ask me if being the primary organizer for a TEDx event is the toughest volunteer OT related leadership role, I will say no… but it is probably amongst the top 5. The primary reason I didn’t put it number 1- because required qualifications to be 1 on paper is the lowest

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: At LAX waiting for my flight to San Antonio to attend #aotainspire22. Sporting one of a few OT masks I will wear for the week. @ LAX Terminal https://t.co/ePbxpLlsrA

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: I think the thing that OTP’s and OTS’s will find the most difficult in organizing TEDx events will be in speaker selection and coaching, technical skills aside (for video editing). Coaching OT peers to speak on the TEDx stage is one thing. Coaching non OT folks for this another.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @jenntsang @smoiz I think you both will like this TEDx talk. https://t.co/bQu1JHZ4G2

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @AbeAOTA And that will be me trying to get checked in later today for #aotainspire22. 😂

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: When curating programming, put yourself in your audience’s shoes. Sequencing matters. 9/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: When curating speeches, it is important to balance between speaker centered, what the TED audience can digest, and content guidelines. 8/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Accept that you will make mistakes. I know I made some last year, even though I was 5 events in! 7/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Prepare for the worst case scenario- can you pull off the event on time if you got virtually no help on essential tasks? In some event types, you are not allowed to have time extensions. So, think carefully before you apply for an event license. 6/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Observe how others conduct their events. Analyze what you like/dislike. 5/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Have a visual of what you can realistically pull off, not what you ideally want. You need to know what your means are before you think about what you can possibly execute. 4/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Put together a time budget and do your best to stay with it! This time budget should be based on your competencies and what support you have available to you. This can get time consuming quick, particularly if you have to do almost everything. 3/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: You should have sound foundations of the basic rules. If you are not sure about specifics, TEDxCommunity and TEDxHub are great places to ask questions and get answers quickly. 2/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: What are some strategies for OTP’s and OTS’s to organize their first TEDx events? A thread. 1/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @_cassietta then don't go to Japan. They have shrimp burgers.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.

tweet: Will I go to WFOT this year? If you were to ask me in 2018, my answer would have been absolutely. Now with what's going on in Ukraine on top of COVID, this will be an 11th hour decision. I am not going to make it rashly.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Since 2014, I spent a ton of money on OT conferences all over, including 2 WFOT conferences. At least I got some return on my investment, since the 2014 WFOT conference set a key foundation for my current autism research opportunities.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: For me, I am in the second category. I already knew very early that my work has value. Plus, going back to USC for a homecoming would be considered a dream return for me in academia. But in order to achieve that dream, I felt I needed to build a competitive CV.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 3. If you are a delegate of your country, pretty much it is a must go. You got to do what you are supposed to do in representing your country, especially when other OTP's in your country have a difficult time making such trips.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 2. If you are a current/aspiring OT academic, this really depends on your long-term professional development goals. It truly depends on much you value presenting in such an arena as well as the networking opportunities. Bottom line is- does the perceived value > financial cost?

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet:
My take on the WFOT conference-

1. If you are an OTP who is trying to make ends meet, I think the price point will be too prohibitive. Experiencing it once will probably be a once in a career item so that you can say that you experienced it.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @AutieAk With Asian culture, I find this pretty tricky. My relatives handled my case and my cousin’s case very differently.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @AutieAk and another thing- if family members speak other languages, can be helpful to train the autistic children to speak such languages, or at least can understand.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @AutieAk and if the autistic children are expected to attend family gatherings- do social stories on expectations. Also, don't assume that every family member is aware that these children are autistic and might make some inappropriate comments unknowingly.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @AutieAk and as an adult child, if they have certain things they want to do, check if they have abilities to navigate these countries on their own. (Parents might need to train their kids to use apps that can help them navigate their environments.)

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @AutieAk another thing- it's not a bad idea to give them choices to attend family gatherings or not, especially if they are visiting family as part of the trip. Sometimes these gatherings can be at potentially sensory overwhelming environments.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: One benefit of waiting until the last minute to register early for WFOT, I get to see how much prices go up. Boy, I already figured I need to change some plans if I were to go.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HGiamarco and I am picking up more this year because I wanted to find ways to help prospective students who need nonstandard shadowing hours. If OT/OTA programs still need these hours, the least faculty can do is to create opportunities like this for those in need.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HGiamarco OT can't burn out the only person who can do this kind of thing so far. The only way OT can pick up the slack is to replicate rather than be cheerleaders.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HGiamarco thing is- we need people to follow my lead. I have been doing this for 4 years now and nobody else has showed any tangible actions to follow the act... even though I am producing concrete evidence that what I do is doable.

tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri I consider myself as a relatively accomplished occupational therapist in autistics' standards. I know fellow autistics in the field would agree with me. The thing is- I am still an unknown quantity amongst autism conference organizers.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri The thing autistic healthcare professionals can bring is that they can blend their lived experiences and professional knowledge well. They can provide something for the autistics and healthcare professionals in such audiences.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri and autistics who are in planning committees of these conferences should network with autistic healthcare professionals.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri Bottom line- organizers need to do their homework! There are more autistics AHP's who come out on social media. Find them and invite them to be keynote speakers, especially ones who are relatively accomplished!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri For the record, I only got invited to speak at 1 autism conference... and that's only because a colleague from India had done her homework on me. If it were exclusively autistic led, I don't think I had a shot.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri and another example- there was an autism conference where some of my professional colleagues attended in Asia Pacific region, my colleagues were like, "Geez! You would have been great as a speaker at this conference!"

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri Based on my experiences, I would say so. For the Stanford Neurodiversity Summit for example, the person in charge of it frankly said to me, "I just didn't know people like you exist! I wish I knew about you earlier!"

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 One thing my NT mentors taught me is the importance of being assertive at the right time. That said... to earn the reputation and respect came at a HUGE cost! Unmasking is impossible nowadays. I think I can only do that when I for sure retire.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 I wouldn't say necessarily clever... it's just that I got quality mentorship and my mentors empowered me to take calculated risks. I couldn't find any autistic mentors who can take me to my promise land, so NT mentors would have to do.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 One thing I have learned over time- because I have spent the time and effort to develop my reputation professionally, editors of these books begin to realize that I should be contributing.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 and that's why maybe it can be beneficial to get in touch with relevant editors of such textbooks. Worst thing they can say is no with your offer to put in your two cents.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 One thing that helped me- because my initial goal was to go back to the uni I graduated from (which is a very competitive school), so I put in a lot of work from my CPD standpoint... so much so that my NT teammates have to wonder how I do it!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 Transition to being a full time academic is not easy. I took it very slow for 2 reasons- a) I know my job history in terms of how I transition best. b) I want to commit to a uni that allows me to grow at my own pace.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 you probably need to train educators in healthcare professional programs on writing case studies featuring autistics.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 and one thing I try to advocate for a widely-used pediatrics textbook- there should be a section on understanding why autistic community doesn't prefer person first language, as well as having an autistic professional as a co-author if there is a section on autism.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 and with the research group I am leading, I am setting the agenda straight on day 1 that my students will be using identity first language instead of person first. Took my students some time to unlearn some of the things they are taught in school.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @SvladCjelli42 I work as a healthcare worker and do my share of autism related profession at my profession's conferences. I knew that all I could do is to use identity first language whenever possible with my presentations. Hopefully that could inspire more about realizing their language use.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @TheAshleyReview @MissPurewal97 For me, I don't really care. But, whoever I date has to understand the nature of my job. It's not easy being someone who works in a profession where their opposite sex represent an overwhelming majority.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MissPurewal97 the only pro about a conservative approach- at least I don't invest too much so that I don't feel crushed when I find out that someone I want to go after for a romantic relationship is already taken.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MissPurewal97 @AutismTalkAspie good question. For me, I desire them. But, I just don't know whether I am the third wheel in such situations or not, especially when I got to know ladies through non-dating sites. So, I tend to err conservatively as a result.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri and my thing with these groups- they shouldn't punish autistic healthcare professionals/researchers who put their professional developments for their career first.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @MxOolong @HeiniMNatri Yes, definitely am aware that it is the first step. But, groups like this typically don't look far and wide enough for autistic healthcare professionals.

tweet: @dawnjoyleong I think I will emerge soon as an interesting collaboration target for autistic elderly research. Autistic healthcare professionals who work with elderly patients don't grow on trees!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @dawnjoyleong Agreed. That's why I am collaborating with some OT friends to do our own autistic elderly research. My OT program is actually impressed with what I am coming up with for its master students!

tweet: @harliepersing_ and in the OT school class that I am teaching now, technically discussion board posts count as attendance grade.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @harliepersing_ In an OTA lab class I taught, attendance was a huge factor. If students missed at least part of the class, they either have to take an oral quiz or write a paper for whatever they missed to get their points back.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @sdietert4574 and I will also say- when my classroom students hear about what I am involved in on and off OT on top of working full time clinically, they are like, "How can you do that? Why are you putting yourself through so much?"

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @sdietert4574 and I will say this- as an adjunct, there are some professors who work multiple jobs to make ends meet. It's underrated amount of pressure to make sure grades are posted within a reasonable time frame. This term is the first term I failed to turn around paper grades in < 7 days.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @sdietert4574 Sometimes OT professors have a tough job, too! If you have a professor or two who can balance between caring for students vs. making sure standards are being met, that's all you can ask for.

tweet: @CAPA_Arthritis @JulieSLalonde My rationale- patient leaders sometimes are also fellow scientists. We have our own career goals, too. Researchers overlooking such for their own gains in research… that is also disrespectful.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @CAPA_Arthritis @JulieSLalonde For me, given that what I have accomplished in my career, I actually wanted to blast some departments for not having the option to allow folks to be part of the research team, which includes being listed as an author on future peer reviewed publications.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @CAPA_Arthritis @JulieSLalonde For me, I value peer reviewed publication opportunities. After all, I see myself in academia for a while and peer reviewed publication is a weak point on my CV.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @JulieSLalonde @CAPA_Arthritis For me, I don’t necessarily care about dollars and cents that much. But, if the researchers are not giving something of value that I am interested at the time and/or I don’t see a long term connection, I will say no.

tweet:
Learned a new Chinese term today- so "motivational interviewing" in Chinese is "动机性访谈".

When you use English when it comes to communicating with peers in medical jargon, you have to intentionally look for what the term is in your native language if you need it.

tweet: @symone_swaby Academia is different setting than clinical IMHO. Full time positions don't come often. So, when an attractive position comes up and you feel you are ready, you should go for it. Otherwise, the opportunity might not pop up for a while.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @symone_swaby yeah- if you are a core faculty, you are more likely to be engaged in the student interview process. That will be when you can see whether the rubrics are fair or not. If you feel that they are not, then you can make some suggestions to improve.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @OnTapPhysio @SandyHiltonPT @APTAtweets @APTAcsm well- hopefully OT can help you all too. Our upcoming annual hybrid conference is also in San Antonio... and the same convention center!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Sure, my approach has some gambling elements. But then again, sharks on Shark Tank sometimes make dud decisions on their show too. 11/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Nowadays I am 10 years in with my professional career, I can’t be as carefree about what I give. I need to be smarter so that I am not taken advantage of. 10/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Last example, if someone asks me to be a research participant for their autism research nowadays, I may not accept the opportunity right away. I have to consider other factors before I accept or decline officially. 9/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Another example, I contributed to an OT textbook in form of its foreword 4 years ago. I got paid $150 for it. It’s still high for me value wise at the time because I needed that item on my CV in the grand scheme of things. 8/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: For example, I pretty much organize TEDx events pro bono nowadays. However, the value is high because I designed a structure that can maximize my talents. Also, money saved is money earned! 7/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: For me, I evaluate each opportunity on a case to case basis. After all, the overall values are not necessarily equal and you can’t necessarily put a price tag on each one. 6/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Like everyone in life, I go through life and priority changes. So, what were meaningful and valuable in my new grad days might not mean as significant now. Of course, the reverse can also be true. 5/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: When applying similar principles to my professional development decisions, that is definitely a risk because I may not be accepting what’s fair value for me right now. Instead, I bank on what might be available for me in the future. 4/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Granted, implied odds are not always realized. It can be because you don’t hit your gin card. It can be because your opponent does something that prevents you from winning the maximum. 3/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: In my undergrad days, I played my share of poker. I came to understand a concept called implied odds. Implied odds in poker = what you can possibly win if you hit your perceived perfect card in the future. 2/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: In some recent tweets, I mentioned about implied value in relation to my decisions regarding my professional development opportunities. Why do I think this way? A thread. 1/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @DrHiralKhatri @DarleneAOTPAC @dawn_sonnier @llouieotr @AOTAInc @AOTAEvents Cheers!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @Gretch19PMA My situation is a bit different. I approach my career decisions like a business. I want fair value for the efforts I spent.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @otbayarea and for someone like me, while I understand not everything can be paid via immediate value, I would take fair implied value. For example, if someone invites to me to be part of autism research, I will only accept if it has publication/future collab opportunities attached.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @otbayarea I took a page out of your playbook... except it is for a research opportunity. I am now telling myself, "What's the long term value of the ask? If the value of the compensation doesn't match well with what I am looking for, I would rather pass... even if the cause is good."

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: This year is my 10th year as an occupational therapist. One question I have to start asking myself when opportunities come my way is- "What's in it for me?" I am not getting any younger. I need to start think about what each opportunity means amongst the grand scheme of things.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: One thing I learned about organizing TEDx events- the heart and passion to organize these events and abilities to make innovations within TED guidelines are more important than having a big budget. (A big budget is nice, however, since this = more organizing options)

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: I can’t wait to see the next edition of Willard and Spackman. I bet future generations of OT/OTA students will be like, “This guy did what?”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @otbayarea and with me- future implied value = future opportunities that are more beneficial for my career goals. This maybe direct or indirect. TEDx will be considered as indirect,. for example, because I won't get any future value from the organizer who invited me.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @otbayarea My take is- if there is future implied value, I will be OK with doing it for what's available. If there is no future implied value, I want to be compensated for what I am worth or what's equivalent for lost time.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @kalypopa Anything to do with TED, I expect everyone involved to follow its event guidelines. It will be like about 1/2 independent study and prep, and 1/2 event planning and execution. My estimation of this year’s model is about 50’ish hours for each student.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @kalypopa I think many OT and OTA educators will tell me, “You needed only 1 hour to think through what the experience will look like for you and the students, as well as whether it is feasible for you to pull it off. Are you kidding me?”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @kalypopa This experience will be virtual. So any prospective student in the US is eligible. The catch is- they will have to work with 2 other prospective students on top of me. This is a packaged deal because it will be 3 additional events.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @otbayarea And just to note- I spent ONLY 1 hour to think about what that would look like and what I expect from the students before I submitted the application. In addition, I am not planning to spend another dime.

tweet: @otbayarea I am tired of some OT programs still requiring prospective students to do observational hours during COVID and they are not providing them any kind of alternative ways to get them completed in spite of knowing that potential options have decreased.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary And personally, as someone who has a strong social media presence in OT, I am tired of trying to please everyone. I just instead focused on being myself and be as professional as I can overall is good enough.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary And for me, unless I do something really wrong or somebody pointed out that I made a major error, I truly don’t care how people judge me at all.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary And aside from refining my style here and there because of what I do in OT over the years, I actually am relatively the same now than 10 years ago… albeit my follower count quadrupled since 7 years ago.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary I am surprised your program faculty has not mentioned my name at all to you as someone who has a diverse network on and off OT. My network consists of 2 pretty different groups outside of OT.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary What I have learned over the years is- as long as I am happy about the balance between when to be personal and when to be professional, one account is fine. I am not uber professional. But, I try to maintain a degree of professionalism because of what I do.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary I do the way I did since I was 26. This account is 10 years old. I chose that way because there are times I say things from the multiple perspectives that I already have and I can’t tease out what’s personal and what’s not.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Sometimes the person you need to talk to is already in your professional network. Sometimes you need to ask yourself the hard question- am I using my professional network optimally? If not, how can I use it better?

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary And I say my point to you because I learned the same lessons during my OTD year. I realize I did not optimally use my professional network. So, I try to make it a point to try to improve a bit each year.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @milkshakezdiary One advice I can give you- please do an inventory of who your professional followers are on all social media. Sometimes the resources you need are right there in front of you and you don’t know about them!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

@AutisticPb Is it a poster or some type of course? If it is some sort of course, you can always make a Powerpoint. 

As someone who has done this type of thing for 12 years, if you are doing any sort of course live, good to find out a system to help you keep track of time.

tweet: @OT_Expert Problem is- more OT folks need to lead by action in this regard. I need more people to start thinking, “Bill has been setting a positive example for us since COVID on this space. If we don’t try now, the skills competence gap between him and us will become greater!”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @nataliehixy @OT_Expert I have a lot of people say to me, “You spent 100-125 hours on top of your day jobs and your OT extracurriculars? Don’t you have any sort of occupational balance after doing this? Also… you are an expert and we aren’t! This may kill us!”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @nataliehixy @OT_Expert Actually it is a win win idea for the profession. Problem is- many find it too challenging, especially when you are factoring in that people may get burned out from day to day work, as well as from doing what they should be doing for their CPD.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @OT_Expert And at a time when prospective students need shadowing hours, I have been thinking about using TEDx as a means to provide such. I am surprised that nobody else in OT even think about that, particularly academics.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @OT_Expert I think the future generations of OT practitioners should learn about what I did in the TEDx organizing space during this time. They should learn that sometimes the window of opportunity for OT to be involved is narrow. Sometimes they got to fake it til they make it.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @OT_Expert Problem is- despite producing concrete evidence that we have the skills and intangibles to be involved, people still don’t buy the idea and/or fear of possible consequences. This pandemic taught me that being opportunistic means taking timely strategic risks.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @FionaPageOT @abichic2 And one twist I uniquely added to my course- students get to watch 3 of the TEDx talks I produced. I want them to think, “He overcame a lot just to become an OT. Now, he is applying what we learned in our classes and do something that nobody else has done yet!”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @FionaPageOT @abichic2 I know the US system is a bit different. But, often students are pretty checked out by the time they took my course. So, my leadership and advocacy lectures focused a bit on breakdowns of legendary OT’s and their career trajectories.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @abbielouise_OT I hear ya. I have a day a week for 3 months possibly at least that I will drive 100 miles each way in LA.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: I think OT and OTA programs across the world need to teach their students proactive ways in #otadvocacy. Organizing TEDx events is definitely one of them. And they should also let students know that such an act are just combined applications of many courses in their programs. 7/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: The time pressure is tough, I have to admit. But in order to slowly convince OT practitioners and students that it is creative and viable avenue for #otadvocacy, I have to keep on proving the impossible possible in hopes that people will follow my lead some time. 6/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Most importantly, I like to pay things forward. TEDx played a role in having my career take off when I was still a relatively new occupational therapist. I enjoyed the experience a lot as a speaker and wanted to give others the same opportunity. 5/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: But, the labor is worth it. I like to see people smiling because they got an opportunity of a lifetime. I like to use it as a walking example of what meaningful occupations can do, even if this occupation doesn't fit me on paper as someone w/ so-so executive function. 4/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Of course, the privilege comes with commitments in time, effort, energy, and money... especially if one is going solo on the organizing effort like myself. It is a labor of love because one can easily spend 100's of hours on 1 event. 3/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Organizing is a proactive action. Organizing places you at the driver's seat at TEDx events. You have the ultimate say of what the program should look like and who the program should feature. 2/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: One thing OT and OTA academics needs to distinguish that speaking at TEDx events and organizing TEDx events are 2 completely different actions. If you get invited to speak, it is definitely an honor and it should be rightfully recognized. But, it is also a reactive action. 1/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @SimonCJay Not overly high or low in terms of emotions. I think I developed that because my 30th was a special one and it will be EXTREMELY difficult to top that. So, my expectations have been kept low ever since.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @ChiariChey It depends on the timing of it. For me, having a legit reason for reasonable accommodations is key.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @melcoach Like for example, I am a healthcare worker. So, if you are an expert in science or health topics, the likelihood of me saying no to you is high, especially if I don’t know you at all.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @melcoach And same goes if you want to get on the TEDx stage as a speaker. Know what have already been presented (content and perspectives wise) is key.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 6. It is not a bad idea to bounce ideas off coworkers on activities recommendations for CEU purposes. 7/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 5. If you feel you are going to be a procrastinator in this department, make sure you set aside some weekends before your renewal date to catch up on your CEU’s. 6/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 4. If you are licensed in multiple states, you got to think about a plan that will meet the requirements for ALL the states that you are licensed in. 5/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 3. After you know your professional trajectory, set criteria for your professional development budget. Are you OK with spending a few hundred dollars a year on conferences or workshops, or go for cheaper CEU sites to save money? 4/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 2. Get to know your professional trajectory. Are you after certifications for your OT practice, or are you OK with just getting by with the rules your state board has for you? 3/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: 1. Know what are required of you. While NBCOT renewal is universal across all states, state to state requirements will vary. So, the first thing you should do when you pass your boards is to get to know the rules early so that you are not panicking. 2/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @teohjouyin In the US, the way we submit our student research to OT conferences is that the primary investigator is not the first author.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @teohjouyin And then not to mention the sensory aspects in interacting in the environment in these settings should also be comparable. And working in 40 nursing homes- that’s comparable too cuz residents can get bounced around in such systems.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @teohjouyin Yeah- I got mad because I got a CAOT conference reviewer wondering where is the client perspective in my students’ thesis group research. Well- technically my work experience in such settings as an OT is more than comparable, since I got to interact w/ nursing home residents.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: I truly wonder- how many OT autism research have autistic folks as the primary principle investigators, instead of additional researchers? I bet that is no more than a handful.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: I mean- if it takes 2 decades for research evidence to translate into OT practice, I don’t have too much time to waste to start advocating for myself and other autistic folks before I become an autistic elder. 8 years working in 40 nursing homes should count as comparable exp.!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: That’s how I felt yesterday when I read a conference reviewer’s comment on my students’ thesis research. If someone sees him/herself as a future patient in an OT setting he/she works at, it’s not wrong for advocacy if he/she knows how long it takes 4 research evidence -> practice https://t.co/ZpmgaKXVAL

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: And for OT folks who don't know about TEDxCountdown events, actually OT students and practitioners make perfect licensees. We actually have sufficient enough science background to coach science speakers on climate change and sustainability if needed be!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @COTECEurope @TEDCountdown I actually organized a TEDxCountdown event with my own speakers pretty much by myself last month. OT community should step up and organize these events in their local or university communities. If I can do it, the rest of OT community can do it!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: If I have my way to organize OT conferences, I probably would have the scores of abstracts in 3 categories- "slam dunk accept", "borderline", or "flat out reject". For "borderline" abstracts, there will be an opportunity for the authors to argue their way to being accepted.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @sally_sallyzen I actually would dare to say my TEDx proposal's reviewer- "Try organize 3 TEDx events with speakers (virtual or on ground) within 3 months with minimal help and a super tight budget! I did it. I want to see YOU do it!"

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @sally_sallyzen and with TEDx stuff, I doubt anybody in OT would have the extensive know-how's as I do. The only way to fairly review these abstracts in my opinion- the reviewers themselves got to have the same experiences of organizing TEDx events for the whole 9 yards w/ minimal help!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @sally_sallyzen If I happen to meet the reviewer, I would have said to him/her, "What more do you want? We tried to make it as unbiased as we could. If my students didn't handle it properly, the study would have been a lot more biased! That wouldn't have been a good one to present, right?"

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @sally_sallyzen and I don't think that reviewer have a clue that my students and I tried to minimize potential biases the best we could... since I very well could cause biases in that study. The fact that my SNF employer refused to let the research recruitment be circulated widely didn't help!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Planning your first TEDx event requires a 2-3 year plan. 1-2 years to pre-plan before coming up with license proposal. (The busier you are, the more time you will need.) Then about a year to actually plan and put all the pieces in motion.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: I think “duh” would be my favorite reaction if I get to talk to OT community about TEDx stuff. Next would be “I was so stupid!” Next would be “Man! More of us should have jumped on that bandwagon in 2009, especially those of us who teach!”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: And to be honest, I wouldn’t have made the connection for OT and TEDx discovery sessions without attending USC OT extravaganza before I started OT school in 2009. When I recalled some of the experiences, I was like, “Some of that could have been discovery session material!”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

My international OT conference plan for now-

2023- OT Australia and RCOT
2024- COTEC-ENOTHE & APOTC
2025- OT Australia (for now)
2026- WFOT and CAOT

Sucks that I will only attend CAOT and RCOT only once, at most twice, during each 4 year period. But, something have to give!

So, I would suggest-

1. Students need to be told that they are ambassadors of their professions. Therefore, it is also their responsibilities to research appropriate language use for different disability communities before posting online. 5/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: When in the field, this step can be easily accomplished if we are mindful to ask questions about our clients’ preferences. After all, even though person first language is taught in OT/OTA programs, what our clients prefer is what we as practitioners should go by. 2/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: As an occupational therapist, one key aspect I am taught in school is about being client and family centered. I personally believe that includes appropriate language use and addressing people with their appropriate pronouns. A thread. 1/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @awoodall19 I go to my share of professional conferences. I never wear a tie and never will. Fortunately, when people ask me why I don’t tie a tie, I just reference Mark Cuban, owner of Dallas Mavericks. That saved me from making possibly lamer excuses. 😂 #actuallyautistic

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @RebeccaTwinley And you can argue for something similar- such as the only way to get direct support is a phone call to customer service in some other industry. No abilities to resolve through chat or email. #actuallyautistic

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @Steph_santosyb I have my neurodivergent mentees too. I let them take ownership of their goals. But if they are very far off between where they are now & they want to be, that’s when I say, “OK. How do you get from point A to point B? Can you tell me what your plans are?” #actuallyautistic

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @BrochaSternOT FYI- for TEDx event videos, the format for YouTube titles often appear as “talk title, speaker name, event name”. So, if you are the licensee of the corresponding event, people actually won’t know that you were behind it unless they look into the event’s profile on TED.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @BrochaSternOT Speaking of authorship, whenever it comes to TEDx event videos, it is easy to do when you are on stage speaking. But, if you are the person behind the scenes, it is OK to toot your horn on OT forums and say, “By the way, I was the brainchild of the video you see here.”

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @LovelyyOt And another tip- we talk about prevention from time to time in our OT/OTA curriculums, there is no such thing of being too early or too often in terms of networking with fellow students or practitioners in the field. Storms can come in big or small during our careers.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @LovelyyOt And I will add a #2 tip- we are in a social media era, so reach out to people. If you feel that sending a connect/follow on social media is too random, consider sending that person a direct message along with the request.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt This is not rocket science. It actually tests many knowledge we learned from our curriculums and our abilities to apply in a nontraditional context.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt That is why you need to bring your task analysis skills to these events. After you take notes, then you got to reflect upon your experience and think about whether if there are certain things can be implemented… just like how OT/OTA students learn their practice trades.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt If people not only attend these events organized by others just as an attendee, but also with a desire to learn from the inside and out, that is one ingredient to succeed. I now attended 30+ of them since COVID. I don’t think anyone in OT has attended that many!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt In the TEDx context, we are late! It has already been 12 years since its inception. We lost so many opportunities to gain leverage, particularly at universities where our programs are at!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt I don’t think peer reviewed journals dig this stuff

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt In my WFOT poster, a message I will send is- why aren’t we leveraging our strengths and applying it in that context? Plus, he is doing what we ask for in our leaders- lead by example! No wonder Bill is mad at the rest of us for not making leaps for years!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt To be honest, this process gets easier with time once you find your comfort zone. But, making that first step ON TOP of what you are supposed to be doing in OT to make ends meet and in terms of CPD is what make many shy away.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt And one thing I always tell people- be honest about what you can do if you receive 0 free help from your community? Do you need to outsource it to professionals? If you do, then you need a revenue generation plan to help balance the books.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt The thing is- like how we learn to be expert clinicians, failures will happen in such quests. We need to learn how to be well prepared and resilient. Why are we not using our best friend- task analysis???

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt Bottom line is- I think many of us fear because only 1 person in this profession tried, as well as the facts that we put our credibility on the line and knowing that we have to be financially responsible for shortfalls can be scary propositions for people to make 1st step.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt And a classic one that we do all the time- if you have questions, ask questions on online forums. There are such places exist like TEDxHub and TEDxCommunity pages on Facebook. There are also links to webcasts available once you find out these pages about tips on different aspects

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @HistoryOt Surprisingly, there are many parallels to how many of us eventually become skilled clinicians. Initial struggles can be opportunities to learn and adapt. It is also important to find our preferences and styles.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @ScudderAudrey Another thing I learned- NT allies are critical, especially if you are a new kind on the block. It's not easy to submit to peer reviewed journals if you don't have mentorship from people who are experienced in reviewing journal articles.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @ScudderAudrey One advantage I do have- now I can be in the driver seat to some autism research once a year because I am a faculty in a masters of healthcare professional program. So, it's nice to get to be the one to set the agenda.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @ScudderAudrey and another thing I am in good position to ask for- if the research is going to be published to peer reviewed journals, I want to be listed as an author... not somewhere in the article on the acknowledgement section.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @ScudderAudrey For me as an #actuallyautistic healthcare professional who is also involve in some autism research, 2 criterias is that the researchers have to treat me as an equal and value the combination of my knowledge + lived experience I bring to the table & give me a meaningful role.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @Ghazardul In terms of accommodations, here is the thing that is not universal. Some institutions are OK with completing such opportunities part time. Some institutions are NOT. That would have been a good accommodation had that been available.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @Ghazardul The primary one was performance based in terms of abilities to produce clinical documentations. She was not able to produce them on a timely manner relative to where she was supposed to be in her experience.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @teohjouyin @Ghazardul In the USA, the "reasonable accommodations" for autistics to complete placements in OT are not universal. What's available in one institution may not be available at another. One example will be having the placement completed part time instead of full time.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @Ghazardul In fact, I am mentoring an autistic student in professional development at the moment. She is in a do-or-die situation right now because she can't afford to fail a clinical rotation any more, which is a crucial requirement for her to obtain licensure to practice in the field.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @Ghazardul But the thing is- in my field in academia for example, one of the key things that is required is a license to practice in the field, academic degree aside. For some autistics, getting there can be a struggle.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: @Ghazardul And I also know this- in such fields, in order to get there, autistics would have to get used to aspects that are not necessarily autistics friendly by nature.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Another thing I learned- it is important to find my style. For me, it is a combination of styles from 2 OT school instructors I had in the past. I liked what each of them offer to my student journey and I try my best to replicate such. 6/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: One thing I have learned going onto my 4th year of teaching- I got to learn which things are non-negotiable and which things can be flexibly adjusted.  After all, students don’t know that their instructors’ hands are tied in certain situations. 5/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L

tweet: I also still do guest lecturing to work on my presence in an OT/OTA classroom. I read students’ social media posts from other programs to be in tune about what my students might be feeling. 4/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @quietcornerz My advice as an #actuallyautistic health professional- out of those on your list, highlight the top few that you absolutely want to address first. Then, as time goes on when the therapist asks you for new needs, then you can refer to that again.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @daAndroGenius How do you define such in terms of non-negotiables? In some health professional fields, % of autistics in them is a microscopic one. My advice is- get to know what you truly need help in and then research on possible certifications that can be beneficial to address such needs.

tweet: @journalautism And I would also say this point- I bring a different dimension to my university's MSOT program thesis groups- a unique combination of clinical insights and autistic lived experiences. I recently had to make my program director aware on IFL vs. PFL issue related to autism.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @journalautism My OT for the last two years get a different perspective about autism because I teach them about leadership and management. That indirectly is also valuable, too, though... because they get to learn how an autistic individual navigating high stakes OT leadership scenes.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @journalautism @ElaineMcgreevy I would argue this- how many autistic health professionals actually have the boldness and savviness to give constructive feedback to the NT editors of their former textbooks and say, "Hey! It would be great that I take a part of the autism chapter."

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @ChristianoVibes @AutisticCallum_ I mean- are we going to say to every autistic who enter into these professions- "We not only hope you survive your education as students in training. BUT, we want you to create + deliver workshops to NT peers AND get involved in research, on top of your clinical day jobs."

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @ChristianoVibes @AutisticCallum_ I also have a counterpoint- autistics represent a very small minority in health professions. Being licensed in their fields of practice is only step 1. Going above and beyond such takes spoons... but is a crucial step after that!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @ChristianoVibes @AutisticCallum_ As an #actuallyautistic health professional, I actually window shop of my colleagues before I decide who to collaborate with in research. Meanwhile, beggars can't be choosers is my approach when it comes to sharing my autistic lived experience + clinical knowledge to my peers.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @thesaltynsassy and here is another thing- #actuallyautistic health professionals are under recognized/appreciated by autism conference organizers, even when some of us are achieving successes equivalent to what Haley Moss is doing in law!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @thesaltynsassy The thing is- at least from my perspective, if autistics want to be in the driver seat of autism-related research, then more autistics should actually attempt to enter health professional fields. Being licensed is only step 1. Going above and beyond such is critical!

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: @thesaltynsassy There are some of us who are #actuallyautistic health professionals who also are involved in autism research at least occasionally. I just finished a pilot study with my thesis group on autistic elderly. My students have told me that it was an interesting experience.

While some people are contemplating, nobody else has taken a step to help in form of stepping up in this department.

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: One thing I am learning to do is to accept my social imperfections. My rationalization is- "No leader is perfect. A primary weakness of mine happened to be my social awkwardness. It might be a sucky one relative to what I am taking on to some people. But, it is what it is." 11/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: On the flip side, saying something like "You know better than that socially." sometimes is not helpful. It can be more helpful to say something like "It might not be your true intentions, but what you did/said come across a certain way to others. I am letting you know that." 10/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: So, I often would ask my friends a favor- "If I slip up socially, please don't wait for it to develop into a pattern. Sometimes I will assume what I do is OK until you tell me so. Trying too hard socially at times is one of my quirks!" 9/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: For me, I feel that I have a double edged sword. I want to continue to make my family and friends proud. But at the same time, taking on additional situations that require my A game socially is very taxing! 8/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: Moreover, the heightened expectations triggered my perfectionism tendencies. That in itself can be stressful.  7/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: All the camouflaging/masking I do come at a potential cost- autistic burnout! Yes, I am a resilient and motivated person. But, to be on socially online and offline for at least 50-75% of my day everyday is difficult. 6/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: A consequence of that is I often camouflage/mask online and offline. But even with my best attempts, though, I still make some occasional blunders. Sometimes it's no big deal because people understand my quirkiness. Sometimes it's a big deal because I can strain relationships. 5/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: In all these roles, I need to make friends and allies. But, there are also a lot of responsibilities in their own ways. In some situations, margins for social blunders are slim to none. 4/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: But then I also have a high stakes leadership position in the OT world in the USA. I also step up to be the licensee for TEDx events in my local community. The thing that these roles have in common- I know I need at least my A- game socially! 3/

name: Bill Wong, OTD, OTR/L
description: OTR/L, OTD, 2x TEDx Talker, TEDx organizer, #actuallyautistic, OTA/OT program adjunct faculty, AOTA VLDC member 2020-2023.
tweet: There are several paid and unpaid roles in my life where I am subjected to high social expectations- online and offline. As an occupational therapist, I need to be professional at my workplaces. In my academic classrooms, I need to conduct myself well online and offline. 2/
